The under-representation of African American, Hispanic/Latino, and Native American students in U.S. universities continues to be an important impediment to the goal of a more equitable society. At the graduate level, under-representation among minority groups is even more striking than at the undergraduate level; for example, African Americans comprised fewer than nine percent of graduate school enrollments and Hispanics comprised just five percent of graduate school enrollments in the early 21st Century in U.S. universities. Under-representation may even be more important in California and Texas, which are the two largest states in the country in terms of population and also two of the most racially and ethnically diverse states. Indeed, both California and Texas are now considered to be "majority-minority" population states.

This collaborative renewal project -- which includes proposals from the University of Texas at Austin, Stanford University, Texas A&M University, and the University of Southern California -- will continue to address the under representation of Hispanics, African Americans, and Native Americans in graduate programs in the Social, Behavioral, and Economic (SBE) sciences at these four institutions. The project will continue to increase the enrollment, retention, and successful completion of under-represented minority (URM) graduate students in the SBE Sciences at alliance institutions, with the long-term intent to increase representation among URM groups on university faculties in the SBE sciences. Two principles continue to guide efforts. Alliance partners will: 1) share ideas, best practices, and resources, and create a network to recruit and retain students for alliance universities; and 2) build on successful initiatives that have already been developed on each of the campuses so that efforts can be as cost-effective and successful as possible. Highly collaborative and innovative methods will be used to improve efforts in recruiting and retaining minority graduate students at the institutions.

Broader Impact

The broader impact of this program is to influence the future of higher education in both
California and Texas. The future of higher education in these two critical majority-minority states in part depends on the ability of universities in these states to diversify the racial/ethnic mix of faculty. The collaborative effort presents one model of how to do so within the SBE sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to help address the under-representation of minority graduate students in the social, behavioral, and economic sciences (SBE) at the University of Texas at Austin. We worked in partnership with alliance collaborators from Texas A&M University, the University of Southern California, and Stanford University throughout the life of this project. The goal of the collaborative project was to increase the enrollment, retention, and successful completion of under-represented minority (URM) graduate students in the SBE Sciences on our campuses, with the long-term intent to increase representation among URM groups on university faculties in the SBE sciences throughout the United States. Our focus at the University of Texas at Austin was on the departments of sociology, government, and anthropology. The intellectual merit of this effort rested in the collaborative and innovative methods that were used to improve efforts toward recruiting, retaining, and graduating URM students. Our strategies were to use the support from the NSF and build on best practices to enhance the career development of URM graduate students in the SBE programs. The broader impact of this program was to influence the future of higher education in the United States. The future of higher education in part depends on the ability of universities to diversify the racial/ethnic mix of faculty to better reach the growing population of racial/ethnic minority students throughout the country.

 

A total of 38 under-represented graduate students in the departments of sociology, government, and anthropology were partially supported over the life of this project at the University of Texas at Austin. To date, 7 of the students have completed their Ph.D. degrees. Of those 7, 5 are in tenure track assistant professor positions (at Princeton University, University of New Mexico, University of Richmond, University of South Carolina, Rhodes College, respectively), 1 is in an adjunct faculty position, and 1 is working as a prestigious postdoctoral fellow at Princeton University. Another 25 of the students are progressing in their respective Ph.D. programs here at UT-Austin. A total of 6 students who were partially supported by this program left UT-Austin prior to completing their Ph.D. degrees. Despite the 6 students who left their programs, the overall success of this program is strongly indicated by the 7 students who have already finished their Ph.D. degrees and are in academic appointments. Should most of the 25 continuing students finish their Ph.D. degrees (and most are on track to do so), the overall success of this program will be even greater.
